slides.title: Merging ü§ù
slides.content:
# Bringing it Together

Once a feature branch is done, you want to bring those changes back into `main`.

`git switch main`
`git merge feature-login`

This creates a new **Merge Commit** that joins the two histories.

slides.title: Fast-Forward Merge
slides.content:
# Smooth Sailing ‚õµ

If `main` hasn't changed while you were working on your feature, Git just moves the `main` pointer forward to your latest commit.

No separate merge commit is created. Linear history.

slides.title: Three-Way Merge
slides.content:
# Diverged History üîÄ

If `main` HAS changed (someone else pushed code), Git has to do some work.

It looks at:
1. Common Ancestor
2. Tip of `main`
3. Tip of `feature`

And creates a new Merge Commit.

slides.title: Merge Conflicts
slides.content:
# The Dreaded Conflict ‚öîÔ∏è

Happens when two people changed the **same lines** in the **same file**.

Git cannot decide which one is correct.

It pauses the merge and asks you to fix it manually.

slides.title: Resolving Conflicts
slides.content:
# Manual Fix üõ†Ô∏è

Open the conflicted file.

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
var color = "blue";
=======
var color = "red";
>>>>>>> feature-login
```

Edit the code to what it SHOULD be, then remove markers, add, and commit.

slides.title: Situation Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: When does a merge conflict typically occur?
quizOptions: When changing the same line in the same file differently

slides.title: Rebasing
slides.content:
# Rewriting History ‚úçÔ∏è

Instead of merging, you can Move your branch to start from the *current* tip of `main`.

`git switch feature`
`git rebase main`

Makes it look like you started your work *after* the latest changes in main. Cleaner linear history.

slides.title: Merge vs Rebase
slides.content:
# The Debate üó£Ô∏è

- **Merge:** Preserves history exactly as it happened. Good for `main`.
- **Rebase:** Creates a straight, clean line. Good for local feature branches before merging.

slides.title: Abort!
slides.content:
# Panic Button üö®

If a merge or rebase goes terribly wrong and you are overwhelmed by conflicts:

`git merge --abort`
`git rebase --abort`

Returns the repo to the state before you started.

slides.title: Squash Merge
slides.content:
# Compression üì¶

Takes all 50 commits from your feature branch and squashes them into ONE single commit on `main`.

Keeps the main history very clean, but loses the granular history of development.

slides.title: Cherry Picking
slides.content:
# Sniper Shot üéØ

Pick a specific commit from another branch and apply it to current branch.

`git cherry-pick a1b2c3d`

Useful for hotfixes.

slides.title: Concept Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What does 'Rebasing' technically do to your commits?
quizOptions: Re-applies them on top of a new base commit
Sends them to the remote server

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Merging ü§ù

Unifying Code.

- **Merge:** Join branches.
- **Conflict:** Overlapping edits.
- **Rebase:** Linear history.
- **Squash:** Condensed history.
